while Statement

The while statement repeatedly executes a statement or block as long as a specified condition is true. It allows you to create loops.
The syntax is as follows:

while(expression)
    statement or block

The "statement or block" is executed repeatedly as long as the conditional expression is true.

The operation is as follows:
(1) First, expression is evaluated; if it is false, the statement or block is not executed.
(2) Execute the statement or block.
(3) Evaluate expression; if the result is true, go to (2), otherwise end the while statement.

In other words, if expression is false from the start, the statement or block is not executed. Also, the expression is not evaluated continuously, but its truth value is checked after each execution of the statement or block.
Also, at point (3), in the case of a block, it temporarily exits the block (meaning variables and such are cleared).

Example:
    while(func()) ;
    /* While func() is true, do nothing and keep evaluating func() */

    while(func()) i++;
    /* While func() is true, keep executing i++ */

    while(i < 5) // while i is less than 5
    {
        func(i);
        i++;
    }

break

The break statement is used when you want to terminate the while loop in the middle.

Example:
    while(true) // Infinite loop unless break is executed
    {
        if(func()) break; // If func() is true, end while
        func2(); // If break is not executed above, it comes here
    }
    // When break is executed, it comes here

continue

The continue statement is used when you want to restart from the evaluation of the conditional expression midway.
When continue is executed, execution moves to (3).

Example:
    var i = 0;
    while(i < 5)
    {
        if(func1()) continue;
        // If func1() is true, the condition i < 5 is checked, and if true,
        // it is executed again from the beginning of the block
        func2();
        i++;
    }

do-while

The do-while statement is the same as the while statement, but it does not check the conditional expression at the beginning.
The syntax is as follows:

do
    statement or block
while(expression);

Since the condition is not checked first, the "statement or block" is executed even if the condition is false at the point of do.
Once the "statement or block" has been executed, the condition is checked; if it is false, the loop is exited, and if true, the statement or block is executed again, and this repeats.
